Understate: The claim may understate the significance of the omission of the words "So help us God" from President Roosevelt's speech at the National World War II Memorial.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that the omission of the words was intentional or deliberate.
Falters at times: The claim falters in accurately representing the context and purpose of the National World War II Memorial.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the omission of the words was due to a societal restriction on mentioning God, without providing substantial evidence for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the omission of the words, such as space limitations or design choices, which are not explored in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the National World War II Memorial does include a reproduction of a portion of President Roosevelt's speech, even if it may not include the specific words "So help us God."
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the omission by implying that it is a deliberate attempt to avoid mentioning God, without sufficient evidence to support this exaggeration.
